contentHtml:
Permutation in String

The wording of this question is quite awful. While it is true that it s2s2s2 needs to contain a permutation of s1s1s1, it would better be described as a substring that s2s2s2 contains a substringsubstringsubstring that is an anagramanagramanagram of s1s1s1.

You are given two string s1s1s1 and s2s2s2. You must return true if s2s2s2 contains a substringsubstringsubstring that is an anagramanagramanagram of s1s1s1.

  • s1="ab"s1 = "ab"s1="ab"
  • s2="eidbao"s2 = "eidbao"s2="eidbao"
    • True, because s2s2s2 contains "ba""ba""ba" which is an anagram of "ab""ab""ab"
    • An anagram contains the same characters with the same count.

How to Solve?

The size of s1s1s1 is the most important factor in solving this problem. If you have:

  • s1="ab"s1 = "ab"s1="ab"

What you want to evaluate is two consecutive characters in the string s2s2s2. If it was size 3, then 3 characters. What kind of algorithm does this suggest we should implement?

Sliding Window

When creating our sliding window, we must consider that the length of s1s1s1 is always going to be either equal to or less than the length of s2s2s2. The size of s1s1s1 is going to the be size of our window.

If s1s1s1 has a size of 2, we care about evaluating two characters in s2s2s2.

What if s2s2s2 is smaller than s1s1s1?

  • Then it is impossible for s2s2s2 to have a substring that is an anagram of s1s1s1. Immediately return false.

What is s1s1s1 and s2s2s2 are the same size?

  • Evaluate if the two strings are anagrams and return TrueTrueTrue if that is the case. Or return true if the two hash maps already match.

Otherwise, we would go about our sliding window algorithm. The most intuitive approach is to use two hash maps for storing the counts of s1s1s1 and s2s2s2 that are the size of s1s1s1. We can do this with the code below:

  • s1Char=Counter(s1)s1Char = Counter(s1)s1Char=Counter(s1)
    • Count all characters in s1s1s1
  • s2Char=Count(s2[:len(s1)])s2Char = Count(s2[:len(s1)])s2Char=Count(s2[:len(s1)])
    • Count the first characters of s2s2s2 up until the length of s1s1s1

Let's assign a left pointer to the beginning of the list and a right pointer to the the length of s1s1s1. This creates a window of length s1+1s1 + 1s1+1.

  • l=0l = 0l=0
    • Decrement s[l]s[l]s[l] from the map.
  • r=len(s1)r = len(s1)r=len(s1)
    • Add s[r]s[r]s[r] to the map.

The tables below demonstrate the behavior of the sliding window. We want to increment the left and right pointer at the same time.

We also want to add the character at the right pointer and remove the character at the left pointer prior to incrementing.

  • s1="ab"s1 = "ab"s1="ab"
  • s2="eidbao"s2 = "eidbao"s2="eidbao"
  • s1Char={"a":1,"b":1}s1Char = \{"a": 1, "b": 1\}s1Char={"a":1,"b":1}
  • s2Char={"e":1,"i":1}s2Char = \{"e": 1, "i": 1\}s2Char={"e":1,"i":1}
    • Before first iteration.
left right s2
l e
i
r d
b
a

  • s1Char={"a":1,"b":1}s1Char = \{"a": 1, "b": 1\}s1Char={"a":1,"b":1}
  • s2Char={"i":1,"d":1}s2Char = \{"i": 1, "d": 1\}s2Char={"i":1,"d":1}
    • Decrement s[l]s[l]s[l] from the hash map.
    • Add s[r]s[r]s[r] to the hash map.
  • Increment lll and rrr.
left right s2

  • s1Char={"a":1,"b":1}s1Char = \{"a": 1, "b": 1\}s1Char={"a":1,"b":1}
  • s2Char={"d":1,"b":1}s2Char = \{"d": 1, "b": 1\}s2Char={"d":1,"b":1}
    • Decrement s[l]s[l]s[l] from the hash map.
    • Add s[r]s[r]s[r] to the hash map.
  • Increment lll and rrr.
left right s2

  • s1Char={"a":1,"b":1}s1Char = \{"a": 1, "b": 1\}s1Char={"a":1,"b":1}
  • s2Char={"b":1,"a":1}s2Char = \{"b": 1, "a": 1\}s2Char={"b":1,"a":1}
    • Decrement s[l]s[l]s[l] from the hash map.
    • Add s[r]s[r]s[r] to the hash map.
  • Increment lll and rrr.

Technically, our hash maps are equal. We can preemptively return if s1Char==s2Chars1Char == s2Chars1Char==s2Char, but I'll continue the table for the sake of the algorithm.

left right s2

  • s1Char={"a":1,"b":1}s1Char = \{"a": 1, "b": 1\}s1Char={"a":1,"b":1}
  • s2Char={"a":1,"o":1}s2Char = \{"a": 1, "o": 1\}s2Char={"a":1,"o":1}
    • Decrement s[l]s[l]s[l] from the hash map.
    • Add s[r]s[r]s[r] to the hash map.
  • No need to increment lll or rrr anymore.
    • rrr will go out of bounds.

If we have found that s1Chars1Chars1Char and s2Chars2Chars2Char do not have the same hash map, there was no substring in s2s2s2 that contains an anagram of s1s1s1. You should return FalseFalseFalse.

Helpful Hints

  • How to create a Counter?
    • char=Counter(s1)char = Counter(s1)char=Counter(s1)
    • Sets characters as keys and their count as values in a hash map.
  • How to increment or decrement a counter?
    • char[s1[i]]+=1char[s1[i]] += 1char[s1[i]]+=1
    • char[s1[i]]=1char[s1[i]] -= 1char[s1[i]]=1

Sliding Window Solution

class Solution:
    def checkInclusion(self, s1: str, s2: str) -> bool:
        # Check if s2's length is smaller than s1
        if len(s2) < len(s1):
            return False

        # Create a hash map for s1 and s2
        # Hash maps are the size of s1
        # And get chars of s2 until size == s1
        s1Char = Counter(s1)
        s2Char = Counter(s2[:len(s1)])

        # Do the hash maps already match?
        if s1Char == s2Char:
            return True
        
        # Assign a left pointer
        l = 0

        # Sliding window starts at 0 to len(s1)
        # r = len(s1)
        for r in range(len(s1), len(s2)):
            # Decrement s[l]'s character
            s2Char[s2[l]] -= 1
            # Increment s[r]'s character
            s2Char[s2[r]] += 1

            # Does s2Char == s1Char now?
            if s2Char == s1Char:
                return True
            
            # Increment the left pointer
            l += 1
        
        return False
title: Permutation in String
